paper_abstract: In measuring the overlap between two sets A and B (e.g. libraries, databases) one is obliged to calculate the overlap O(A vertical bar B) of A with respect to B (i.e. the fraction of elements of B that are also in A) and of O(B vertical bar A) of B with respect to A (i.e. the fraction of elements in A that are also in B). Theoretically this requires two samples. In this paper we explain that one sample can suffice to determine confidence intervals for both O(A vertical bar B) and O(B vertical bar A). The paper closes with the example of measuring the overlap between the secondary sources in mathematics MathSciNet and Zentralblatt MATH and with a remark on the estimation of the Jaccard index.
